Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: NSF INCLUDES: An Integrated Approach to Retain Underrepresented Minority Students in STEM Disciplines

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Georgia, Florida International University, Savannah State University, Clark Atlanta University and Fort Valley State University will lead this Design and Development Launch Pilot to address enhancing recruitment, retention, productivity and satisfaction of historically underrepresented minority (URM) undergraduate students who enroll in STEM graduate programs at primarily white (PWI) and research intensive (RI) universities. This project was created in response to the Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES) program solicitation (NSF 16-544). The INCLUDES program is a comprehensive national initiative designed to enhance U.S. leadership in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) discoveries and innovations focused on NSF's commitment to diversity, inclusion, and broadening participation in these fields. The INCLUDES Design and Development Launch Pilots represent bold, innovative ways for solving a broadening participation challenge in STEM.

The full participation of all of America's STEM talent is critical to the advancement of science and engineering for national security, health and prosperity. Our nation is advancing knowledge and practices to address the STEM education practices for retaining and educating URM undergraduate STEM students at our nation's research intensive universities (RIs). This project, NSF INCLUDES: An Integrated Approach to Retain Underrepresented Minority Students in STEM Disciplines, has the potential to advance a collaborative approach by a group of organizations to improve the success of URM undergraduates in STEM disciplines.

The collaborating universities will work together for the purposes of empowering URM students to more effectively navigate STEM undergraduate and graduate education at minority serving institutions (MSIs) and PWIs, and for transforming the culture of PWIs and RIs. The team plans to use evidence-based approaches to gain insights into cultural differences that impact the success of URM STEM students. Three interventions will be included in the pilot study: (1) undergraduate URM student exchanges between MSIs and PWIs, (2) collaborative inquiry to engage URM students in social science research about issues and experiences of under-representation in STEM, and (3) the adaptation of resources from the Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching and Learning (CIRTL) to train STEM faculty to embrace diversity and improve teaching in diverse classroom settings. The project team plans to develop strategies to scale approaches and develop an alliance of institutions to maximize potential project outcomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long term goal of the INCLUDES project was to enhance recruitment, retention, productivity and satisfaction of underrepresented minority students enrolled in STEM graduate programs. The immediate goals were to involve undergraduate minority students to 1) Effectively navigate STEM undergraduate program at the minority serving institution (MSI) and 2) to participate in cultural experiences in diversified settings. To accomplish these goals SSU participated in the alliance with UGA and other MSIs a) To learn from the exchange experience for URM STEM students and b) Develop a collaborative inquiry approach to engage students as social science researchers who facilitate mutual learning and generate transferable findings around issues and experiences. We learned from our experiences to identify the best practices that will enhance participation and success of URM students in STEM disciplines at the PWI institutions.  Following was accomplished during the grant period:

 

1)      One SSU student participated in student exchange program at UGA in fall 2017. The student also participated in collaborative inquiry at the home institution (SSU). Student reported and presented her experiences on collaborative inquiry by reporting some interesting data by interacting with Caucasian population at the beach.

 

2)      SSU student who participated in the exchange program at UGA enrolled for 13 credit hours in fall 2017. The student was enrolled in Biology, Principles of Chemistry II, Scientific Diving I and Elementary Spanish. Her overall performance at UGA was not satisfactory. Student reported that she was not used to attending large classes and experienced that the Professors were not willing to provide help during the lectures. However, the student also never took advantage of the tutorial services provided at UGA. Her unsatisfactory performance may be attributed to the change in environment, seeking help from the tutorial services to hide her weaknesses and perhaps, working while attending school at UGA. It is to be noted that the student earned a B grade in elective course Scientific Diving.

 

From the collaborative inquiry point of view, the student further reported that the instructors at UGA were dispassionate about teaching which made her feel marginalized and powerless. The student was satisfied with the summer research experience at UGA but did express the concern that the summer research experience is not a substitute to prepare for academic year engagement. We also had other challenges in the area of exchange logistics which included: Inter-institutional student advisement, complications of course credit transfer, housing reservations for returning students, and transient student vs national student exchange, we realized that there is need for dedicated ?Exchange Manager? to ensure efficient and effective student exchange program.

 INCLUDES project provided students with the opportunity to interact with individuals in the community and provided them the experience in how to communicate with individual of different color and race. Although the student performance at UGA was not satisfactory in Fall 2017 but the feedback provided us a roadmap which will help us in guiding students in future to ensure satisfactory performance.
